subject: Fix regression handling relative paths in environment
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-23 20:19:38.000000000', 'files': ['heatclient/common/template_utils.py', 'heatclient/tests/unit/test_template_utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient/commit/4d253e7a9108a8e6e014e18c2f6412ece7b3bd0d', 'message': "Fix regression handling relative paths in environment

7627e1bae53747e1471caf632dfc1b6edf2e26cf introduced new code to add the
environment to the files mapping, so server side resolution of multiple
environments is possible.

However, the environment added is wrong when you're handling those with
relative paths inside, we must add the resolved version or the keys
don't map to keys in the files map, an you get an error when we try
to locate the file on the server.

Evidently we lack adequate functional test coverage of this, which can
be addressed via a heat patch, but I added a unit test illustrating
the problem.

Change-Id: I3bd2cd48623e4ad1b4067f4cefc7ddff30b9e88d
Closes-Bug: #1560106
"}]
commit_message:
Fix regression handling relative paths in environment

7627e1bae53747e1471caf632dfc1b6edf2e26cf introduced new code to add the
environment to the files mapping, so server side resolution of multiple
environments is possible.

However, the environment added is wrong when you're handling those with
relative paths inside, we must add the resolved version or the keys
don't map to keys in the files map, an you get an error when we try
to locate the file on the server.

Evidently we lack adequate functional test coverage of this, which can
be addressed via a heat patch, but I added a unit test illustrating
the problem.

Change-Id: I3bd2cd48623e4ad1b4067f4cefc7ddff30b9e88d
Closes-Bug: #1560106
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/68/296768/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.assertEqual(json.dumps(expected_env), files['file:///home/my/dir/env1.yaml']) def test_process_environment_relative_file_tracker(self): self.m.StubOutWithMock(request, 'urlopen') env_file = '/home/my/dir/env.yaml' env_url = 'file:///home/my/dir/env.yaml' env = b''' resource_registry: "OS::Thingy": a.yaml ''' request.urlopen(env_url).AndReturn( six.BytesIO(env)) request.urlopen('file:///home/my/dir/a.yaml').AndReturn( six.BytesIO(self.template_a)) request.urlopen('file:///home/my/dir/a.yaml').AndReturn( six.BytesIO(self.template_a)) self.m.ReplayAll() self.assertEqual( env_url, utils.normalise_file_path_to_url(env_file)) self.assertEqual( 'file:///home/my/dir', utils.base_url_for_url(env_url)) env_file_list = [] files, env = template_utils.process_multiple_environments_and_files( [env_file], env_list_tracker=env_file_list) # Verify expected_env = {'resource_registry': {'OS::Thingy': 'file:///home/my/dir/a.yaml'}} self.assertEqual(expected_env, env) self.assertEqual(self.template_a.decode('utf-8'), files['file:///home/my/dir/a.yaml']) self.assertEqual(['file:///home/my/dir/env.yaml'], env_file_list) self.assertEqual(json.dumps(expected_env), files['file:///home/my/dir/env.yaml'])

commit_message:
Modify location to point to action

API call to create cluster/node return a location pointed to
resource itself, this patch change location pointed to action.

APIImpact

Change-Id: Ic1e81514f5d9a122d44cb709c3aa1699c8cb6cd7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/75/298175/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'action': 'fake_action' self.assertEqual('/actions/fake_action', resp['location'])

commit_message:
Updates all repo SHAs to prepare for Mitaka release

This patch includes updates of all SHA's and pip, wheel and setuptools
pins.

Due to Bug #1561947, the backend glance store has been changed from swift
to file in the AIO gate. This has been done becuase the glance store project
has an issue with session that causes it to be incompatible with swift. Being
that the master integration gate is depending on this change to go it is
needed to temporarily disable the swift image store in glance until this issue
is fixed.

The branch updater sciprt was modified to search for and update roles if they're
found within the default or user provided role path. This change is resolving
bash errors that happen when the script is run in mitaka+.

Related-Bug: 1561947
Change-Id: I2e09e3e0abb61f5e97e2af7b283f0aed6dadd853
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
[WIP] Test to see if this fixes the gate

python-setuptools is imported by the jinja2 module.  This is problematic
for from source builds, as two copies of setuptools end up being installed.

Another option is just to remove setuptools.

jinja2 is required I believe by the zookeeper integration.

Change-Id: I37c2ebc6bd0921f81d65a3eb03f9e8ed5ff8b030

added_lines: import datetime import timefrom oslo_utils import timeutilsfrom neutron.common import constants elif key == constants.CHANGED_SINCE: if getattr(model, constants.UPDATED, None) is not None: data = filters[constants.CHANGED_SINCE][0] try: datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(time.mktime( time.strptime(data, constants. RESOURCE_TIMESTAMP_FORMAT))) except Exception: msg = _("The input changed_since must be like" " YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ") raise n_exc.InvalidInput(error_message=msg) changed_since_string = timeutils.parse_isotime(data) changed_since = (timeutils. normalize_time(changed_since_string)) query = query.filter(model.updated_at >= changed_since)

commit_message:
Scrub residual device before connect volume in cinder

Scrub residual device paths, sd devices and multipath device shells before
connect volume in cinder:
1.Scrub the devices in the host that with same iqns and luns of target;
2.Scrub /dev/sd* which belong to multipath device but not in /dev/disk/by_path;
3.Scrub multipath devices shell.

Change-Id: Ia7cd240f4640326d083bfa261242e53cfb620287
Closes-Bug: #1553730
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/82/297582/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_concurrency import lockutilsfrom cinder.brick import iscsiscrubsynchronized = lockutils.synchronized_with_prefix('cinder-driver-') self.scruber = iscsiscrub.IscsiScrubberManager( True if CONF.use_multipath_for_image_xfer else False) @synchronized('_connect_device') def _scrub_residual_devices(self, conn): try: self.scruber.scrub_residual_devices(conn) except processutils.ProcessExecutionError as ex: LOG.error(_LE("scrub residual devices error: %(ex)s") % {'ex': ex}) @synchronized('_connect_device') # scrub residual device paths, sd devices and # multipath device shells self._scrub_residual_devices(conn)

commit_message:
Docs cleanup: volume command help

This formats the volume command help text consistent with the rest of OSC,
adds some reference targets and some explanation text to some commands.

No functional changes have been made, only cosmetic/help output.

Change-Id: Ib86ec3ca58bdea5f33078ced3ec3583b2be0e89a

commit_message:
Neutron: Add rejoin_neutron function

When using Neutron, L3 agent, and OpenVSwitch, the IP address is moved
from the physical interface, ethX, over to the OVS bridge, br-ex. This
is done by ./stack.sh during the neutron L3 configuration.  This
movement is required in order to maintain connectivity to this IP
address.

When the host machine is rebooted OR the network service is restarted,
the IP address is associated with the physical interface, ethX, once
again and the IP address is no longer reachable.

Update rejoin-stack.sh to move the IP address (if necessary) using
the same logic that is invoked during stack.sh

Closes-Bug: #1521790
Change-Id: I0c80bb79c2bd1b5098f6dda0803798fed9d13463
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/57/252457/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash # **move_ip.sh** # ``move_ip.sh`` moves the IP address and the route from the public interface over to the OVS bridge if # the l3 agent was enabled. This logic is done during stack.sh, but if then system is rebooted, # connectivity to the IP address is lost. # Keep track of the current devstack directory. TOP_DIR=$(cd $(dirname "$0")/.. && pwd) # Load local configuration source $TOP_DIR/openrc # Source neutron library source $TOP_DIR/lib/neutron-legacy if is_service_enabled q-l3; then _move_neutron_addresses_route "$PUBLIC_INTERFACE" "$OVS_PHYSICAL_BRIDGE" False "inet" if [[ $(ip -f inet6 a s dev "$PUBLIC_INTERFACE" | grep -c 'global') != 0 ]]; then _move_neutron_addresses_route "$PUBLIC_INTERFACE" "$OVS_PHYSICAL_BRIDGE" False "inet6" fi fi

commit_message:
Don't merge: Replace duplicated code by iotop lib

This is for making sure the possiblity if we can replace the code
looks like duplicated with GPL liscenced kernel code.

This is only to try to replace iotop related but not yet for nice.
So still WIP and don't merge right now.

Change-Id: Ie1af9dfa3c4efeccd2e11b9f600ea95a3d5bc249
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/32/294432/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """"""import iotop """Binding to `setpriority`""" """See `man 2 setpriority`""" """Availability of `nice`""" """Binding to `ioprio_set` syscall""" """See `man 2 ioprio_set`""" return self._c_ioprio_set(iotop.IOPRIO_WHO_PROCESS, pid, ioprio_value) syscall_nr = iotop.find_ioprio_syscall_number( iotop.IOPRIO_SET_ARCH_SYSCALL) if syscall_nr is not None: return syscall_nr else: raise EnvironmentError('ionice (ioprio_set) not available') ioprio_cls = iotop.PRIORITY_CLASSES.index(ioprio_cls) return (ioprio_cls << iotop.IOPRIO_CLASS_SHIFT) | ioprio_data """Availability of `ionice`"""
deleted_lines: '''''' '''Binding to `setpriority`''' '''See `man 2 setpriority`''' '''Availability of `nice`''' '''Binding to `ioprio_set` syscall''' # from linux/ioprio.h PRIORITY_CLASSES = [None, 'rt', 'be', 'idle'] IOPRIO_WHO_PROCESS = 1 IOPRIO_CLASS_SHIFT = 13 IOPRIO_SET_ARCH_SYSCALL = [ ('alpha', '*', 442), ('arm*', '*', 314), ('i*86', '*', 289), ('ia64*', '*', 1274), ('parisc*', '*', 267), ('powerpc*', '*', 273), ('s390*', '*', 282), ('sparc*', '*', 196), ('sh*', '*', 288), ('x86_64*', '32bit', 289), ('x86_64*', '64bit', 251), ] '''See `man 2 ioprio_set`''' return self._c_ioprio_set(self.IOPRIO_WHO_PROCESS, pid, ioprio_value) arch = os.uname()[4] bits = platform.architecture()[0] for cand_arch, cand_bits, syscall_nr in self.IOPRIO_SET_ARCH_SYSCALL: if fnmatch.fnmatch(arch, cand_arch) and \ fnmatch.fnmatch(bits, cand_bits): return syscall_nr raise EnvironmentError('ionice (ioprio_set) not available') ioprio_cls = self.PRIORITY_CLASSES.index(ioprio_cls) return (ioprio_cls << self.IOPRIO_CLASS_SHIFT) | ioprio_data '''Availability of `ionice`'''

subject: Make DHCP agent scheduler physical_network aware
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-24 17:30:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/0b3b3fe32a823001eb6a1769c7b993512fbc462e', 'message': 'Make DHCP agent physical_network aware

This patch makes the DHCP scheduler network reachability aware
when using the ML2 plugin. If ML2 has any agent based drivers
loaded, their bridge/interface mappings are consulted when scheduling
a flat or VLAN network, and overlay_network_types on the agent
is consulted if its an overlay network. If no agent based drivers
are loaded, the network is considered reachable.

Closes-Bug: #1478100
Change-Id: I0501d47404c8adbec4bccb84ac5980e045da68b3
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-07-24 19:56:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/2babb6bd9d6047af5ce6c842140caee5003e7072', 'message': "Make DHCP agent physical_network aware

This patch makes the DHCP scheduler network reachability aware
when using the ML2 plugin. This solves a problem where when using
VLAN/flat provider networks, dnsmasq may be scheduled to a DHCP agent
that has no reachability to the network its supposed to serve as
determined by the network's physical_network tag and the host
the network was scheduled to.

If ML2 has any agent based drivers loaded, their bridge/interface
mappings are consulted when scheduling a flat or VLAN network,
and overlay_network_types on the agent is consulted if its an
overlay network. If no agent based drivers are loaded,
the network is considered reachable.

Here's a diagram to explain the use case:
http://i.imgur.com/NTBxRxk.png

Both networks on physical_network 1 should be served by DHCP agent 1.

I had to change neutron/tests/unit/scheduler/test_dhcp_agent_scheduler.
DHCPAgentWeightSchedulerTestCase because it was using the ML2 plugin,
but instead of creating a network through the plugin it was adding
records directly to the Network table, meaning that those networks
had no segments. Hosts cannot reach a network without a segment,
and because this scenario is synthetic I changed the tests to create
networks through the plugin layer.

Closes-Bug: #1478100
Change-Id: I0501d47404c8adbec4bccb84ac5980e045da68b3
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-07-24 20:00:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/6a02a3420733686f8740351c4413cec3944a776d', 'message': "Make DHCP agent scheduler physical_network aware

when using the ML2 plugin. This solves a problem where when using
VLAN/flat provider networks, dnsmasq may be scheduled to a DHCP agent

Both networks on physical_network 1 should be served only by DHCP agent

and overlay_network_types on the agent is consulted if its an
overlay network. If no agent based drivers are loaded,
the network is considered reachable.

I had to change neutron/tests/unit/scheduler/test_dhcp_agent_scheduler.
DHCPAgentWeightSchedulerTestCase because it was using the ML2 plugin,
but instead of creating a network through the plugin it was adding
records directly to the Network table, meaning that those networks
had no segments. Hosts cannot reach a network without a segment,
and because this scenario is synthetic I changed the tests to create
networks through the plugin layer.

Closes-Bug: #1478100
Change-Id: I0501d47404c8adbec4bccb84ac5980e045da68b3

DHCPAgentWeightSchedulerTestCase because it was using the ML2 plugin,
but instead of creating a network through the plugin it was adding
records directly to the Network table, meaning that those networks
had no segments. Hosts cannot reach a network without a segment,
and because this scenario is synthetic I changed the tests to create
networks through the plugin layer.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1478100
Co-Authored-By: Cedric Brandily <zzelle@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I0501d47404c8adbec4bccb84ac5980e045da68b3
"}, {'number': 17, 'created': '2015-11-17 22:32:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/022f822b0ff259fc5a2c53aabcc14ff15bdcfbaa', 'message': "Make DHCP agent scheduler physical_network aware

This patch makes the DHCP scheduler network reachability aware
when using the ML2 plugin. This solves a problem where when using
VLAN/flat provider networks, dnsmasq may be scheduled to a DHCP agent
that has no reachability to the network its supposed to serve as
determined by the network's physical_network tag and the host
the network was scheduled to.

Here's a diagram to explain the use case:
http://i.imgur.com/NTBxRxk.png

Both networks on physical_network 1 should be served only by DHCP agent
1, never 2.

If ML2 has any agent based drivers loaded, their bridge/interface
mappings are consulted when scheduling a flat or VLAN network,
and overlay_network_types on the agent is consulted if its an
overlay network. If no agent based drivers are loaded,
the network is considered reachable.

I had to change neutron/tests/unit/scheduler/test_dhcp_agent_scheduler.
DHCPAgentWeightSchedulerTestCase because it was using the ML2 plugin,
but instead of creating a network through the plugin it was adding
records directly to the Network table, meaning that those networks
had no segments. Hosts cannot reach a network without a segment,
and because this scenario is synthetic I changed the tests to create
networks through the plugin layer.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1478100
Co-Authored-By: Cedric Brandily <zzelle@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I0501d47404c8adbec4bccb84ac5980e045da68b3

"}, {'number': 28, 'created': '2015-12-23 00:05:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/5985917479a7db8d813ee13e6e1ccd1d63bfc90a', 'message': 'Make DHCP agent scheduler physical_network aware

This patch makes the DHCP scheduler network reachability aware
by querying the plugin. This solves a problem where when using
VLAN/flat provider networks, dnsmasq may be scheduled to a DHCP agent
that has no reachability to the network its supposed to serve as
determined by the network's physical_network tag and the host
the network was scheduled to.

Here's a diagram to explain the use case:
http://i.imgur.com/NTBxRxk.png

Both networks on physical_network 1 should be served only by DHCP agent
1, never 2.

This change provides an implementation for ML2 plugin delegating host
filtering to its mechanism drivers: it aggregates the filtering done by
each mechanism or disables filtering if any mechanism doesn't overload
default mechanism implementation[1] (for backward compatibility with
out-of-tree mechanisms). Every in-tree mechanism overloads the default
implementation: OVS/LB/SRIOV mechanisms use their agent mapping to filter
hosts, l2pop/test/logger ones return empty set (they provide to "L2
capability").

This change provides a default implementation[2] for other plugins
filtering nothing (for backward compatibility), they can overload it to
provide their own implementation.

I had to change neutron/tests/unit/scheduler/test_dhcp_agent_scheduler.
DHCPAgentWeightSchedulerTestCase because it was using the ML2 plugin,
but instead of creating a network through the plugin it was adding
records directly to the Network table, meaning that those networks
had no segments. Hosts cannot reach a network without a segment,
and because this scenario is synthetic I changed the tests to create
networks through the plugin layer.

[1] neutron.plugin.ml2.driver_api.MechanismDriver.\
      filter_hosts_with_network_access
[2] neutron.db.agents_db.AgentDbMixin.filter_hosts_with_network_access

Closes-Bug: #1478100
Co-Authored-By: Cedric Brandily <zzelle@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I0501d47404c8adbec4bccb84ac5980e045da68b3
'}, {'number': 29, 'created': '2016-01-08 23:04:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/d1fa9b04016313f1ecbacd3f350b3df20eba59e9', 'message': 'Make DHCP agent scheduler physical_network aware

'}, {'number': 32, 'created': '2016-01-14 23:15:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/151f4dd9c13d4ef5e3a4d2df5e94cbbf2f061ee5', 'message': 'Make DHCP agent scheduler physical_network aware

Currently neutron DCHP scheduler assumes that that every server running
a dhcp-agent can reach every network. Typically the scheduler can
wrongly schedule a vlan network on a dhcp-agent that has no reachability
to the network it's supposed to serve (ex: network's physical_network
not supported).

Typically such usecase can append if:

* physical_networks are dedicated to a specific service and we don't
  want to mix dnsmasqs related to different services (for
  isolation/configuration purpose),
* physical_networks are dedicated to a specific rack (see example
  diagram http://i.imgur.com/NTBxRxk.png), the rack interconnection can
  be handled outside of neutron or inside when routed-networks will be
  supported.

This change makes the DHCP scheduler network reachability aware by
querying plugin's filter_hosts_with_network_access method.

This change provides an implementation for ML2 plugin delegating host
filtering to its mechanism drivers: it aggregates the filtering done by
each mechanism or disables filtering if any mechanism doesn't overload
default mechanism implementation[1] (for backward compatibility with
out-of-tree mechanisms). Every in-tree mechanism overloads the default
implementation: OVS/LB/SRIOV mechanisms use their agent mapping to filter
hosts, l2pop/test/logger ones return empty set (they provide to "L2
capability").

This change provides a default implementation[2] for other plugins
filtering nothing (for backward compatibility), they can overload it to
provide their own implementation.

Such host filtering has some limitations if a dhcp-agent is on a host
handled by multiple l2 mechanisms with one mechanism claiming network
reachability but not the one handling dhcp-agent ports. Indeed the
host is able to reach the network but not dhcp-agent ports! Such
limitation will be handled in a follow-up change using host+vif_type
filtering.

[1] neutron.plugin.ml2.driver_api.MechanismDriver.\
      filter_hosts_with_network_access
[2] neutron.db.agents_db.AgentDbMixin.filter_hosts_with_network_access

commit_message:
Make DHCP agent scheduler physical_network aware

Currently neutron DCHP scheduler assumes that that every server running
a dhcp-agent can reach every network. Typically the scheduler can
wrongly schedule a vlan network on a dhcp-agent that has no reachability
to the network it's supposed to serve (ex: network's physical_network
not supported).

Typically such usecase can append if:

* physical_networks are dedicated to a specific service and we don't
  want to mix dnsmasqs related to different services (for
  isolation/configuration purpose),
* physical_networks are dedicated to a specific rack (see example
  diagram http://i.imgur.com/NTBxRxk.png), the rack interconnection can
  be handled outside of neutron or inside when routed-networks will be
  supported.

This change makes the DHCP scheduler network reachability aware by
querying plugin's filter_hosts_with_network_access method.

This change provides an implementation for ML2 plugin delegating host
filtering to its mechanism drivers: it aggregates the filtering done by
each mechanism or disables filtering if any mechanism doesn't overload
default mechanism implementation[1] (for backward compatibility with
out-of-tree mechanisms). Every in-tree mechanism overloads the default
implementation: OVS/LB/SRIOV mechanisms use their agent mapping to filter
hosts, l2pop/test/logger ones return empty set (they provide to "L2
capability").

This change provides a default implementation[2] for other plugins
filtering nothing (for backward compatibility), they can overload it to
provide their own implementation.

Such host filtering has some limitations if a dhcp-agent is on a host
handled by multiple l2 mechanisms with one mechanism claiming network
reachability but not the one handling dhcp-agent ports. Indeed the
host is able to reach the network but not dhcp-agent ports! Such
limitation will be handled in a follow-up change using host+vif_type
filtering.

[1] neutron.plugin.ml2.driver_api.MechanismDriver.\
      filter_hosts_with_network_access
[2] neutron.db.agents_db.AgentDbMixin.filter_hosts_with_network_access

Closes-Bug: #1478100
Co-Authored-By: Cedric Brandily <zzelle@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I0501d47404c8adbec4bccb84ac5980e045da68b3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/31/205631/32 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @classmethod def get_hosts_with_network_access(cls, plugin, context, network_id): access_filter = getattr( plugin, 'get_agents_with_access_to_network', None) if not access_filter: return None return [agent['host'] for agent in access_filter(context, network_id)] @classmethod def filter_unreachable_hosts(cls, agents_dict, hosts_with_access): filtered_agents = [ agent for agent in agents_dict['hostable_agents'] if agent['host'] in hosts_with_access] agents_dict['hostable_agents'] = filtered_agents # Get either the old value, or a lower value of we filtered any agents_dict['n_agents'] = min( len(filtered_agents), agents_dict['n_agents']) return agents_dict hosts_with_access = self.get_hosts_with_network_access( plugin, context, network['id']) if hosts_with_access is None: return agents_dict return self.filter_unreachable_hosts(agents_dict, hosts_with_access)

commit_message:
OSC plugin for orchestration template validate

This change implements "openstack orchestration template validate" command
Based from the existing heat commands:
   heat template-validate

This is different from the stack create/update --dry-run
which used the preview api, this uses the validate api.

Change-Id: Icf5794ad6bb35574a060f095d7ef10e6a46ca2fe
Blueprint: heat-support-python-openstackclient
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/25/288725/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: orchestration_template_validate = heatclient.osc.v1.template:Validate

commit_message:
Wait longer for AMT firmware from deep sleep

Reuse options [amt]max_attempts and [amt]action_wait to
control the wait time to wake up AMT firmware.
This will try to wake up AMT firmware three times and wait 10s
before next wake up call by default.

Closes-Bug: #1504023
Change-Id: I45baa502dea41d43e48c4268f5f5b47f69407dfe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/06/264106/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_service import loopingcallfrom ironic.common.i18n import _LE, _LW cfg.IntOpt('max_attempts', default=3, help=_('Maximum number of times to attempt an AMT operation, ' 'before failing')), cfg.IntOpt('action_wait', default=10, help=_('Amount of time (in seconds) to wait, before retrying ' 'an AMT operation')), ping the IP five times which is enough to wake it up. In the case where AMT interface is in a deep sleep, there is a need to wait longer. So make use max_attempts and action_wait options to control the time. def _wait(status): if status['iter'] >= CONF.amt.max_attempts: LOG.error(_LE('Unable to wake up AMT interface on node ' '%(node_id)s.'), {'node_id': node.uuid}) raise exception.AMTConnectFailure() try: utils.execute(*cmd_args) except processutils.ProcessExecutionError: LOG.warning(_LW('Unable to wake up AMT interface on node ' '%(node_id)s - Attempt %(attempt)s times of ' '%(max_attempt)s '), {'node_id': node.uuid, 'attempt': status['iter'] + 1, 'max_attempt': CONF.amt.max_attempts}) status['iter'] += 1 else: LOG.debug(('Successfully wake up AMT interface on node ' '%(node_id)s.'), {'node_id': node.uuid}) AMT_AWAKE_CACHE[node.uuid] = now raise loopingcall.LoopingCallDone() status = {'iter': 0} timer = loopingcall.FixedIntervalLoopingCall(_wait, status) timer.start(interval=CONF.amt.action_wait).wait()
deleted_lines: from ironic.common.i18n import _LE ping the IP five times which is enough to wake it up. try: utils.execute(*cmd_args) except processutils.ProcessExecutionError as err: LOG.error(_LE('Unable to awake AMT interface on node ' '%(node_id)s. Error: %(error)s'), {'node_id': node.uuid, 'error': err}) raise exception.AMTConnectFailure() else: LOG.debug(('Successfully awakened AMT interface on node ' '%(node_id)s.'), {'node_id': node.uuid}) AMT_AWAKE_CACHE[node.uuid] = now

commit_message:
Functional: use pined magnum client

On Magnum gate, some other project will depend on magnum client (like heat),
so always use latesed code of magnum cient may break them.

Change-Id: Ie355d30e34a6fca085cc8c69cf92c3f781e110e3

commit_message:
Remove NodeNotOrphan exception type

The NodeNotOrphan exception is not interesting at all. It is basically
one type of bad request. This patch proposes a removal of it.

Change-Id: I008251ef6ffc50677bc62cdbbe00483f5ff88b14

commit_message:
Refactor API version range support

This patch refactors the API version check so that the min/max versions
are defined only for OpenStack APIs. Previously, these definitions are
placed in a global scope which is incorrect.

partial-bp: api-microversioning
Change-Id: I8a59b3ab94dab664da29f85a5b7d2c7043ffeab6

added_lines: Refer to the Manila client command-line help for information on how toThe CapabilitiesFilter uses the following for matching operators: * **=** This chooses a host that has equal to or greater than the resource specified. This has the same behavior as in vcpus case. For example, if gpu = 2, a host with gpus of 2 or more can be chosen. The resource to be consumed by the instance will be the given number. So, in the example, even though a host with gpu 4 is chosen, only 2 gpus will be used by the instance. * **<=, >=, ==, !=** Same as C notation. * **s==, s!=, s>=, s>, s<=, s<** The "s" indicates it is a string comparison. These choose a host that satisfies the comparison of strings in capability and specification. For example, if "fft-lib s== fftw", a host that reports capability of "fftw" will be chosen. * **<in>** This chooses a host that has partially matching string in the capability. For example, if "<in> sse4" is used, it will match a host that reports capability of "sse4_1" or "sse4_2". * **<or>** This chooses a host that has one of the items specified. If the first word in the string is <or>, another <or> and value pair can be concatenated. Examples are "<or> 3", "<or> 3 <or> 5", and "<or> 1 <or> 3 <or> 7". This is for string value only. * **<is>** This chooses a host that matches a boolean capability. An example extra-spec value would be "<is> True". thick. So, a Manila pool will always report thin_provisioning as True or
deleted_lines: Refer to the manila client command-line help for information on how toRefer to the CapabilitiesFilter for matching operators. For example, to match a boolean capability the extra-spec value would be '<is> True'. thick. So, a manila pool will always report thin_provisioning as True or

commit_message:
Implement multisite VIM feature

Added support for multisite OpenStack VIM feature through a new
'nfvo' extension. This also enables remote VNF life cycle manage-
ment through the VIM Id parameter.

Implements: blueprint multi-site-vim
Depends-On: I3c08945f24343288c2c5614ab4b472d68a1e1d47

Change-Id: I7dd19a0c1ce948474bb3069073b3608ce265beb4

subject: Block subtractive operations in DB migrations
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-23 15:33:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/cc648a6bfe247c44dea5565784ffb149113154ee', 'message': "Block subtractive operations in DB migrations

To achieve rolling upgrades we need to make non-backward-compatible DB schema
migrations in a very specific manner that spans through 3 releases. In
particular we need to be very careful when dropping or altering columns
and tables.

This commit adds a test that blocks all the ALTER and DROP operations
from DB migrations. It allows to specify exceptions from this rule for two
purposes:
* Some DROP/ALTER migrations aren't subtractive (e.g. dropping a
  constraint).
* When following the process we've designed for non-backward-compatible
  migrations, we should be able to drop first unused columns or tables
  in O release.

The test is based on similar one implemented in Nova.

commit_message:
Block subtractive operations in DB migrations

To achieve rolling upgrades we need to make non-backward-compatible DB schema
migrations in a very specific manner that spans through 3 releases. In
particular we need to be very careful when dropping or altering columns
and tables.

This commit adds a test that blocks all the ALTER and DROP operations
from DB migrations. It allows to specify exceptions from this rule for two
purposes:
* Some DROP/ALTER migrations aren't subtractive (e.g. dropping a
  constraint).
* When following the process we've designed for non-backward-compatible
  migrations, we should be able to drop first unused columns or tables
  in O release.

The test is based on similar one implemented in Nova.

Implements: bp online-schema-upgrades

Change-Id: I07df721e5505abe17e45427c05b985b7e923a010

added_lines: import fixtures class BannedDBSchemaOperations(fixtures.Fixture): """Ban some operations for migrations""" def __init__(self, banned_resources=None): super(MigrationsMixin.BannedDBSchemaOperations, self).__init__() self._banned_resources = banned_resources or [] @staticmethod def _explode(resource, op): print('%s.%s()' % (resource, op)) # noqa raise Exception( 'Operation %s.%s() is not allowed in a database migration' % ( resource, op)) def setUp(self): super(MigrationsMixin.BannedDBSchemaOperations, self).setUp() for thing in self._banned_resources: self.useFixture(fixtures.MonkeyPatch( 'sqlalchemy.%s.drop' % thing, lambda *a, **k: self._explode(thing, 'drop'))) self.useFixture(fixtures.MonkeyPatch( 'sqlalchemy.%s.alter' % thing, lambda *a, **k: self._explode(thing, 'alter'))) def migrate_up(self, version, with_data=False): # NOTE(dulek): This is a list of migrations where we allow dropping # things. The rules for adding things here are very very specific. # Insight on how to drop things from the DB in a backward-compatible # manner is provided in Cinder's developer documentation. # Reviewers: DO NOT ALLOW THINGS TO BE ADDED HERE WITHOUT CARE exceptions = [] # NOTE(dulek): We only started requiring things be additive in # Liberty, so ignore all migrations before that point. LIBERTY_START = 61 if version >= LIBERTY_START and version not in exceptions: banned = ['Table', 'Column'] else: banned = None with MigrationsMixin.BannedDBSchemaOperations(banned): super(MigrationsMixin, self).migrate_up(version, with_data)

subject: firewall: don't warn about a driver that does not accept bridge
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-24 15:20:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/ac8bc49f157682631a4993705e77d09eb8a3589f', 'message': "firewall: don't warn about a driver that does not accept bridge

Drivers that do not need the bridge parameter are safe to ignore it.
Actually, the base abstract interface for those drivers does not allow
to pass the new parameter.

Ideally, the the base class __init__ signature would change to accept
the argument, but we can't do it without breaking API.

So instead, just handle both types of drivers - those that accept the
additional argument, and those that don't. And don't assume the latter
are somehow wrong.

Change-Id: Iceee46f63669b28e3a34d207216d864f1bfa5cf8
Closes-Bug: #1561243
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-03-24 17:46:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/b6b9a1d37537c3da5721b7bc05b943cf958b1e5a', 'message': "firewall: don't warn about a driver that does not accept bridge

Drivers that do not need the bridge parameter are safe to ignore it.
Actually, the base abstract interface for those drivers does not allow
to pass the new parameter.

Ideally, the the base class __init__ signature would change to accept
the argument, but we can't do it without breaking API.

commit_message:
firewall: don't warn about a driver that does not accept bridge

Drivers that do not need the bridge parameter are safe to ignore it.
Actually, the base abstract interface for those drivers does not allow
to pass the new parameter.

Ideally, the base class __init__ signature would change to accept the
argument, but we can't do it without breaking API.

So instead, just handle both types of drivers - those that accept the
additional argument, and those that don't. And don't assume the latter
are somehow wrong.

Change-Id: Iceee46f63669b28e3a34d207216d864f1bfa5cf8
Closes-Bug: #1561243

commit_message:
Make network segment table available for standalone plugin

Some standalone plugins, such as networking-ovn, are expecting
to store provider network information in neutron database, but
we have no table, like other extensions do, for provider
network extension defined.

This patch moves NetworkSegment table out of the ML2 code tree.
The API methods to operate segments are also moved, but stub
methods are still kept in the ml2 db API.

Co-Author: Miguel Lavalle <malavall@us.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I2c4f78fce591486ded63252af13fc0c60d02a3e8
Partially-Implements: blueprint routed-networks

commit_message:
Install only required packages

Add other-requirements.txt to install
only required packages that we need for testing and not extra packages
that are installed by default.

This change is self-testing.

Change-Id: Id66f1a150cde886c33ae977efcb2c4337f160d0c

subject: Zero Downtime Re-indexing Error Handling.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-28 23:29:18.000000000', 'files': ['searchlight/elasticsearch/plugins/utils.py', 'searchlight/cmd/manage.py', 'searchlight/elasticsearch/plugins/base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/searchlight/commit/531447d28045e0da15a85bf942ee03d7707b3679', 'message': 'Zero Downtime Re-indexing Error Handling.

See spec:
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/searchlight-specs/specs/mitaka/zero-downtime-reindexing.html

The Zero Downtime code is deficient in the error handling department.
One cleanup method too few. If we get any unrecoverable exceptions
while creating/preparing the indexes or aliases, we cannot continue.
In this case we need to roll back and undo any changes we made.

Change-Id: I5591d5208f75015f93b8431e73d2d7c7f5f2e167
Closes-Bug: #1557003
(cherry picked from commit bc9eeaa9bac867eb28c07077fe7ee4cc4af9db5f)
'}]
commit_message:
Zero Downtime Re-indexing Error Handling.

See spec:
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/searchlight-specs/specs/mitaka/zero-downtime-reindexing.html

The Zero Downtime code is deficient in the error handling department.
One cleanup method too few. If we get any unrecoverable exceptions
while creating/preparing the indexes or aliases, we cannot continue.
In this case we need to roll back and undo any changes we made.

Change-Id: I5591d5208f75015f93b8431e73d2d7c7f5f2e167
Closes-Bug: #1557003
(cherry picked from commit bc9eeaa9bac867eb28c07077fe7ee4cc4af9db5f)

commit_message:
make/update_subnetpool_dict call _dict_extend

Now the extension fields were not being added to the response for
subnetpool, and when update subnetpool, the response of updated was not
contain any extensions which based on 'standard_attr'.

This patch add 'call _extend_dict' functions to make subnetpool support
for extending dict.

Change-Id: I7bc449aa079d84869b2a707b36bbbfb22d540cc5
Closes-Bug: #1548161

commit_message:
Zero Downtime Re-indexing Error Handling.

See spec:
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/searchlight-specs/specs/mitaka/zero-downtime-reindexing.html

The Zero Downtime code is deficient in the error handling department.
One cleanup method too few. If we get any unrecoverable exceptions
while creating/preparing the indexes or aliases, we cannot continue.
In this case we need to roll back and undo any changes we made.

Change-Id: I5591d5208f75015f93b8431e73d2d7c7f5f2e167
Closes-Bug: #1557003
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/searchlight refs/changes/79/293079/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """Prepare a new index for usage with this listener. We need to be caled immediately after a new index is created, but before it gets associated with an alias. Prepping means we will add the settings and mapping for this listener's document type. """ try: self.engine.indices.put_settings(body=index_settings, index=index_name) except Exception as e: LOG.error(encodeutils.exception_to_unicode(e)) try: self.engine.indices.put_mapping(index=index_name, doc_type=doc_type, body=mapping) except Exception as e: # Log the error and continue to the next doc type. LOG.error(encodeutils.exception_to_unicode(e))

subject: L3HA: Do not wrap create/delete in transaction
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-02 00:22:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/36387376366a428b808a72cd6fa170195d62741f', 'message': "L3HA: Do not wrap create/delete in transaction

This is unsafe when calling ML2 because ML2 assumes that its
functions will not be called inside of a transaction. This is
not only an issue for drivers that try to do DB lookups using
a different session in the post commit operation, but it's a
big issue for the delete methods.

The delete subnet and network methods in ML2 have 'while True'
loops that catch concurrency errors and retry the operation after
looking up info. If these are called inside a transaction, the
lookups will contain stale information and it can lead to the
while True loop never terminating!

Closes-Bug: #1551958
Change-Id: I33dc084ed15e5491fdda19da712a746ca87fbc8c
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-03-04 16:28:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/2d2bf46da51984fa3ba1f7b0c214a43571471c9a', 'message': "L3HA: Do not wrap create/delete in transaction

functions will not be called inside of a transaction. This is
not only an issue for drivers that try to do DB lookups using
a different session in the post commit operation, but it's a
big issue for the delete methods.

The delete subnet and network methods in ML2 have 'while True'
loops that catch concurrency errors and retry the operation after

commit_message:
L3HA: Do not wrap create/delete in transaction

This is unsafe when calling ML2 because ML2 assumes that its
functions will not be called inside of a transaction. This is
not only an issue for drivers that try to do DB lookups using
a different session in the post commit operation, but it's a
big issue for the delete methods.

The delete subnet and network methods in ML2 have 'while True'
loops that catch concurrency errors and retry the operation after
looking up info. If these are called inside a transaction, the
lookups will contain stale information and it can lead to the
while True loop never terminating!

Closes-Bug: #1551958
Change-Id: I33dc084ed15e5491fdda19da712a746ca87fbc8c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/20/286920/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

" "Exception: %(exc)s"), {'obj': obj['id'], 'exc': e}) return obj, value
deleted_lines: with context.session.begin(subtransactions=True): obj = create_fn() try: value = create_bindings(obj['id']) except Exception: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): try: delete_fn(obj['id']) except Exception as e: LOG.error(_LE("Cannot clean up created object %(obj)s. " "Exception: %(exc)s"), {'obj': obj['id'], 'exc': e}) return obj, value

commit_message:
Also package congress_tempest_tests

The folder congress_tempest_tests has to be packaged in order for the
Debian packaging CI to work. Otherwise, we get:
ImportError: No module named congress_tempest_tests.plugin
when running templest.

Please allow this distribution specific patch to reach upstream.

Change-Id: If14b5afec201068af7cc6fc903cdf6fa72887c2a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/15/297715/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
WIP: Fail devstack if some variables are not set

We call various commands to set certain variables. Add some checks to
make sure those variables are set and fail if they are not.

commit_message:
WIP: Keep the console logs for all boots

This patch adds a libvirt hook that saves the VM console log everytime
it shutdown. This is great for troubleshooting because it allow us to
see what happened with the VM on every boot instead of only the last one.

Devstack: Remove QEMU hook at ./unstack
Remove the libvirt QEMU hook to rotate the logs when ./unstack is
invoked. Otherwise it will always rotate the logs even if the
IRONIC_VM_LOG_ROTATE is set to False in a subsequently ran.

This commit also makes the path to the hook configurable.

Devstack: Make sure libvirt's hooks directory exists
Before copying the QEMU hook to the libvirt's hooks directory, make sure
that the path exists. Some distros do not create it by default (e.g
Fedora 23).

(cherry-picked from openstack/ironic commit 2f6dce97384718f6a35d1d9a12d3d1ae5128a271)
(cherry-picked from openstack/ironic commit d9a2a62ac009ac07ec1ebdb1626896b5bb592bc7)
(cherry-picked from openstack/ironic commit ac54456a8ed225512fd5702952a454675280db75)

Change-Id: Iba692d7ec761a79bd2bca8fb09df38461459f107
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/48/293748/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash VM_LOG=%LOG_DIR%/$1 VM_ACTION=$2 if [ $VM_ACTION = "release" ]; then if [ ! -f "${VM_LOG}_console.log" ]; then return 0 fi NOW=$(date +"%d-%m-%Y-%H:%M:%S") mv "${VM_LOG}_console.log" "${VM_LOG}_console_${NOW}.log" fi

deleted_lines: def _set_boot_device_order(node, boot_device): """Set boot device order configuration of AMT Client. :param node: a node object :param boot_device: the boot device :raises: AMTFailure :raises: AMTConnectFailure """ client = amt_common.get_wsman_client(node) doc = _generate_change_boot_order_input(device) method = 'ChangeBootOrder' options = pywsman.ClientOptions() options.add_selector('InstanceID', 'Intel(r) AMT: Boot Configuration 0') try: client.wsman_invoke(options, resource_uris.CIM_BootConfigSetting, method, doc) except (exception.AMTFailure, exception.AMTConnectFailure) as e: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): LOG.exception(_LE("Failed to set boot device %(boot_device)s for " "node %(node_id)s with error: %(error)s."), {'boot_device': boot_device, 'node_id': node.uuid, 'error': e}) else: LOG.info(_LI("Successfully set boot device %(boot_device)s for " "node %(node_id)s"), {'boot_device': boot_device, 'node_id': node.uuid})def _enable_boot_config(node): """Enable boot configuration of AMT Client. :param node: a node object :raises: AMTFailure :raises: AMTConnectFailure """ client = amt_common.get_wsman_client(node) method = 'SetBootConfigRole' doc = _generate_enable_boot_config_input() options = pywsman.ClientOptions() options.add_selector('Name', 'Intel(r) AMT Boot Service') try: client.wsman_invoke(options, resource_uris.CIM_BootService, method, doc) except (exception.AMTFailure, exception.AMTConnectFailure) as e: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): LOG.exception(_LE("Failed to enable boot config for node " "%(node_id)s with error: %(error)s."), {'node_id': node.uuid, 'error': e}) else: LOG.info(_LI("Successfully enabled boot config for node %(node_id)s."), {'node_id': node.uuid}) _set_boot_device_order(node, boot_device) _enable_boot_config(node)

subject: Block delete_(network|subnet) transactioned calls
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-01 21:17:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/714461e79e58c662950b69d53dbe21979ff673d4', 'message': "Block delete_(network|subnet) transactioned calls

These functions assume that they won't be called inside of a
transaction for two reasons. The first is an infinite loop that
will only terminate if it can actually retrieve the latest
information from the database. The second is that ML2's post-commit
operations are expected to occur after data was actually committed
so mechanism drivers that do DB lookups using a different session
may break.

This adds an explicit guard that prevents these two functions from
being called within an active DB session. The rest of the ML2
functions should eventually be converted to this style as well
(see the partial bug).

Change-Id: I5c00b186585369ef6c8e2b9cb5a43b8bba0e5a7c
Partial-Bug: #1540844
Closes-Bug: #1551958

so mechanism drivers that do DB lookups using a different session

This adds an explicit guard that prevents these two functions from

This adds an explicit guard that prevents these two functions from

commit_message:
Block delete_(network|subnet) transactioned calls

These functions assume that they won't be called inside of a
transaction for two reasons. The first is an infinite loop that
will only terminate if it can actually retrieve the latest
information from the database. The second is that ML2's post-commit
operations are expected to occur after data was actually committed
so mechanism drivers that do DB lookups using a different session
may break.

This adds an explicit guard that prevents these two functions from
being called within an active DB session. The rest of the ML2
functions should eventually be converted to this style as well
(see the partial bug).

Related-Bug: #1551958
Partial-Bug: #1540844
Change-Id: I5c00b186585369ef6c8e2b9cb5a43b8bba0e5a7c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/43/286843/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import functoolsdef transaction_guard(f): @functools.wraps(f) def inner(self, context, *args, **kwargs): if context.session.is_active: raise RuntimeError(_("Method called within an active db session.")) return f(self, context, *args, **kwargs) return inner @transaction_guard @transaction_guard

commit_message:
Add creation of new log folder for Horizon

The previous Horizon logging fix missed the part of creating new folder,
this fix adds it.

Change-Id: I14da441ebb6de94964326c0a1b02ae1480b080bd
Closes-Bug: 1561073
(cherry picked from commit 8d96d639c8918e52c6d4d0a0bdeba299ea12bb86)

added_lines: # NOTE(sbezverk) since Horizon is now storing logs in its own location, /var/log/horizon # needs to be created if it does not exist if [[ ! -d "/var/log/kolla/horizon" ]]; then mkdir -p /var/log/kolla/horizon fi if [[ $(stat -c %a /var/log/kolla/horizon) != "755" ]]; then chmod 755 /var/log/kolla/horizon fi

subject: Fix keystone-manage config file path
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-28 20:12:58.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/cmd/manage.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/dd38543bdc2a11b38162fda616fd7933f1539397', 'message': "Fix keystone-manage config file path

Without this patch, the keystone-manage command looks for a default
keystone.conf relative to the installed executable. In a developer's
case this is likely to be relative to <venv name>/bin/keystone-manage.
If installed via distro packages this will be something like
/usr/bin/keystone-manage. The keystone developer documentation
instructs the developer to copy the sample config file into the etc/
directory of the keystone source directory[1], which is not necessarily
related to where the keystone-manage executable is installed. This
patch causes the keystone-manage command to search for
etc/keystone.conf relative to the python source file,
keystone/cmd/manage.py, which will always be in the same place relative
to the keystone repo's etc/ directory. If installed via distro packages
this will cause keystone-manage to search for the config in something
like /usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages, but since it falls back to
searching the standard oslo.cfg directories, the behavior won't change.

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/keystone/developing.html#configuring-keystone

Closes-bug: #1561099

Change-Id: Icf9caac030e62deb17ce5df3a82737b408591ac0
(cherry picked from commit 139f892fecf4ce645e3a7a6a7d1087a94f402f89)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix keystone-manage config file path

Without this patch, the keystone-manage command looks for a default
keystone.conf relative to the installed executable. In a developer's
case this is likely to be relative to <venv name>/bin/keystone-manage.
If installed via distro packages this will be something like
/usr/bin/keystone-manage. The keystone developer documentation
instructs the developer to copy the sample config file into the etc/
directory of the keystone source directory[1], which is not necessarily
related to where the keystone-manage executable is installed. This
patch causes the keystone-manage command to search for
etc/keystone.conf relative to the python source file,
keystone/cmd/manage.py, which will always be in the same place relative
to the keystone repo's etc/ directory. If installed via distro packages
this will cause keystone-manage to search for the config in something
like /usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages, but since it falls back to
searching the standard oslo.cfg directories, the behavior won't change.

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/keystone/developing.html#configuring-keystone

Closes-bug: #1561099

Change-Id: Icf9caac030e62deb17ce5df3a82737b408591ac0
(cherry picked from commit 139f892fecf4ce645e3a7a6a7d1087a94f402f89)

Partially-implements: automatic-resource-creation

added_lines: HEAT_RESOURCE_MAP = { "flavor": "OS::Nova::Flavor" } def _add_resources_tpl(self, heat_tpl, hot_res_tpl): heat_dict = yaml.safe_load(heat_tpl) for res, res_dict in hot_res_tpl.iteritems(): for vdu, vdu_dict in res_dict.iteritems(): res_name = vdu + "_" + res heat_dict["resources"][res_name] = { "type": HEAT_RESOURCE_MAP[res], "properties": {} } for prop, val in vdu_dict.iteritems(): heat_dict["resources"][res_name]["properties"][prop] = val heat_dict["resources"][vdu]["properties"][res] = { "get_resource": res_name } return yaml.safe_dump(heat_dict) res_tpl = toscautils.check_remove_resr_tpl(vnfd_dict) heat_template_yaml = \ self._add_resources_tpl(heat_template_yaml, res_tpl)

commit_message:
Revert "Tolerate both new and old setuptools"

setuptools 20.3 was released 2016-03-15T21:11:21 which solves the
vendorised excpetion issue from 20.2.2

This is a partial revert or commit
  5bf6d89969f28a10f1e9b763f007e6a3099a3c22.

This original commit contained 2 changed that were squashed.  We only
want to revert the stuptools relevant parts not the other-requirements
changes.

commit_message:
Turn the orchestration client reference into a property

Use a property instead of a function. This is more in line with how the
clients are referenced with openstackclient, thereby making it easier
to switch to the a Heat OSC plugin in the future.

Change-Id: I849593e6328f3883235e9ae34232f92d6b3c0d80
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/52/224752/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: orchestration_client = clients.tripleoclient.orchestration orchestration_client = clients.tripleoclient.orchestration
